questions.prompt: 1. In BG 4.1, Krishna says He spoke this yoga to whom in an earlier age?
questions.feedback: Krishna says He spoke this yoga system to the Sun-god Vivasvan in ancient times.

questions.prompt: 2. In BG 4.2, why has this yoga knowledge been lost from the world?
choices: It was too difficult to understand
Because of the lapse of time, the succession has been broken
It was deliberately hidden by the demigods
questions.feedback: Due to the lapse of time, the succession of teachers was broken and the knowledge was lost.

questions.prompt: 3. In BG 4.3, Krishna tells Arjuna that because of their intimate relationship, He is revealing this yoga to him. What relationship does Krishna specifically refer to?
choices: As friends in a previous life
questions.feedback: Krishna reveals this yoga because they were intimate friends in previous lives; this was a secret even among the demigods.

questions.prompt: 4. In BG 4.4-5, how many births have Arjuna and Krishna passed through, and who remembers them all?
choices: Thousands of births; no one remembers
Seven births; only the great sages
questions.feedback: Both have passed through many births, but Krishna remembers them all while Arjuna does not.

questions.prompt: 5. In BG 4.6, Krishna says that although He is unborn and eternal, what do I do?
choices: I remain in the spiritual sky
I descend from the spiritual world by My internal energy whenever there is a decline of righteousness
I am invisible to all beings
questions.feedback: Though unborn and eternal, Krishna descends whenever there is a decline in dharma.

questions.prompt: 6. In BG 4.7-8, for what two purposes does Krishna appear in this world?
choices: To enjoy material pleasures and to teach rituals
To punish the demons and to reward the virtuous
To deliver the pious and to annihilate the miscreants, and to establish principles of religion
To establish a kingdom and to gain fame
questions.feedback: Krishna appears to deliver the pious, annihilate the miscreants, and re-establish the principles of religion.

questions.prompt: 7. In BG 4.9, what happens to one who understands Krishna's transcendental nature and activities?
choices: He attains liberation and returns to the spiritual world
He becomes famous in this world
questions.feedback: One who understands Krishna's transcendental nature and activities attains liberation (no rebirth) and returns to the spiritual world.

questions.prompt: 8. In BG 4.10, how many types of people are freed from material life through devotion to Krishna?
choices: Those who are attracted by His qualities, whose minds are fully engaged in Him, who are always seeking His association, and who long for His love
Only those who renounce the world
questions.feedback: Four types of people are freed: those attracted to His qualities, those with minds engaged in Him, those seeking His association, and those longing for His love.

questions.prompt: 9. In BG 4.13, the four divisions of society (varnas) are created based on what?
choices: Quality of work and inclination (guna and karma)
questions.feedback: The four varnas are created based on the qualities and work (guna and karma) of individuals, not on birth.

questions.prompt: 10. In BG 4.15, what is the path that even wise men follow?
choices: The path laid down by great men of the past
questions.feedback: Great men of the past have set the path that even wise men follow; this is the traditional way.

questions.prompt: 11. In BG 4.16, what is the apparent confusion about action and inaction?
choices: Some say all actions are forbidden
Some say all action is bad; others say action is necessary
Some say work always brings bad results
Some say meditation replaces all action
questions.feedback: The path of action is very difficult to understand; even the learned are confused about what is action and what is inaction.

questions.prompt: 12. In BG 4.17-18, what kind of action is considered sinless?
choices: Action done with attachment to results
Action understood within intelligence, when all desire is removed
questions.feedback: The person who sees inaction in action and action in inaction is understood to have knowledge and has performed all sinless action.

questions.prompt: 13. In BG 4.19, what is the characteristic of a wise person?
choices: He performs many rituals and sacrifices
All his works are performed with no desire for fruitive results
He constantly travels to holy places
He avoids all types of work
questions.feedback: A wise person is one whose works are devoid of selfish motive; all actions are consumed by the fire of knowledge.

questions.prompt: 14. In BG 4.20, what is the state of one who is liberated in this life?
choices: He has no longing for results; his actions are burnt up in the fire of knowledge
questions.feedback: One who neither expects nor desires the results of action, and has no attachment, is considered already liberated.

questions.prompt: 15. In BG 4.21, what does a man of steady mind do?
choices: He renounces the results of action and is satisfied with what comes naturally; he is free from envies
He gathers wealth from all sources
questions.feedback: A man of steady mind is content with whatever is obtained naturally, free from envy, and transcends the duality of gain and loss.

questions.prompt: 16. In BG 4.23, what is the condition of the liberated soul who acts?
choices: His actions bind him to karma
All acts are devoid of binding force; he is not bound by his actions
questions.feedback: For one who is liberated, all activities are devoid of karmic reactions; he is not bound by actions.

questions.prompt: 17. In BG 4.24, what is Brahman according to this verse?
choices: That offering is Brahman; the oblation is Brahman; the act of offering is Brahman; by Brahman it is offered into the fire of Brahman
questions.feedback: This verse describes the non-dual nature of action and sacrifice: all aspects are Brahman, the Absolute Reality.

questions.prompt: 18. In BG 4.26, what is the position of one who offers the senses in the fire of self-control?
choices: He is considered wise and pure
He loses his ability to work
questions.feedback: One who offers the senses in the fire of self-control is wise and pure, accepted as a great yogi.

questions.prompt: 19. In BG 4.29-30, what are some of the different types of sacrifices Krishna mentions?
choices: Breath control, study of the Vedas, sense control, penances, and meditation
questions.feedback: Krishna mentions various sacrifices including breath control, Vedic study, sense control, penances, meditation, and knowledge.

questions.prompt: 20. In BG 4.33, what does Krishna say is superior to all material sacrifices?
questions.feedback: Knowledge sacrifice is superior to all material sacrifices; all actions in their totality culminate in knowledge.

questions.prompt: 21. In BG 4.34, how does one gain knowledge?
choices: Through books and intellectual study alone
By inquiring submissively and rendering service to the spiritual master; the wise give knowledge to one who has approached them
questions.feedback: By approaching a bona fide spiritual master, inquiring submissively, and rendering service, one gains knowledge.

questions.prompt: 22. In BG 4.35, what happens when one gains knowledge from a spiritual master?
choices: He no longer performs any actions
He never again suffers illusion because he sees that all living beings are part of the Supreme
He becomes famous in the world
questions.feedback: With knowledge from a spiritual master, one sees all living beings as part of the Supreme and never again experiences illusion.

questions.prompt: 23. In BG 4.37, what is the result of the fire of knowledge?
choices: It burns up all sins completely
questions.feedback: The fire of knowledge burns up all the consequences of fruitive actions; all sinful reactions are completely burned up.

questions.prompt: 24. In BG 4.38, what destroys the knowledge-fire?
choices: Nothing in this world destroys it; knowledge is eternal
questions.feedback: Nothing in this world is as pure and powerful as transcendental knowledge; nothing can destroy it.

questions.prompt: 25. In BG 4.39, what is the result of perfect control of the senses through yoga practice?
choices: He attains peace of mind through satisfaction in knowledge; all the results of actions are consigned to the Lord
questions.feedback: By controlling the senses and practicing yoga, one attains peace through transcendental knowledge and is released from all actions.
